snippet: By making its own hardware, Google could end up more squarely in Apple’s sights. The jury’s findings in the case could potentially force Google to adjust its software, too.
abstract: Google, by making its own hardware, could end up more squarely in Apple's sights, which won a patent infringement suit against Samsung; jury in Samsung trial found that features built into Google's Android, and not just features added by Samsung, violated Apple patents, potentially forcing Google to adjust its software.

headline.main: Samsung Case Puts Apple Closer to Google Fight
headline.print_headline: Samsung Case Puts Apple Closer to Fight With Google

byline.original: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER and BRIAN X. CHEN

snippet: Apple asked a federal judge to block the sale of more than a half dozen Samsung smartphones, after a jury found that Samsung had infringed a series of Apple's mobile patents.
abstract: Apple asked a federal judge to block the sale of more than a half dozen Samsung smartphones, after a jury found that Samsung had infringed a series of Apple's mobile patents.

headline.main: Apple Seeks Order Blocking Sale of Samsung Products

snippet: Apple’s $1 billion court win against Samsung translated Monday into a jump in its market value and a marked dip for several other technology stocks.

headline.main: IPhone Verdict Plays Out in Stocks

snippet: Buoyed by a legal victory, Apple shares reached a record high before closing at $675.68 even as volume dropped ahead of a speech by the Federal Reserve chairman.
abstract: Shares of Apple, buoyed by a legal victory, reach a record high in the lightest full day of trading of 2012.

headline.main: On Slow Day of Trading, Apple Keeps Soaring
headline.print_headline: On Slow Day of Trading, Apple Keeps Soaring

snippet: Apple's victory on Friday in a patent lawsuit against Samsung could, if upheld, give its rivals a kick in the pants to create more original products, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday's New York Times. Whether consumers respond by buying more disti...
abstract: Apple's victory on Friday in a patent lawsuit against Samsung could, if upheld, give its rivals a kick in the pants to create more original products, Nick Wingfield reports in Monday's New York Times. Whether consumers respond by buying more distinctive devices is another question entirely.

headline.main: Daily Report: After Apple-Samsung Verdict, Concern About Innovation

snippet: Plus: waiting for the Fed, marginal tax rates through the years, tweets of the week — and how many people are you expecting at your funeral?
abstract: Plus: waiting for the Fed, marginal tax rates through the years, tweets of the week — and how many people are you expecting at your funeral?

headline.main: This Week in Small Business: Trash Talk

snippet: For companies that emphasize distinctive design, the Samsung patent verdict was a validation of their efforts.
abstract: Smartphone patent verdict against Samsung is welcome validation for Apple and other Silicon Valley companies that make and protect technologies with distinctive design; still, flourishing of innovative products prompted by verdict may not translate into sales success for Apple's rivals; industry expresses concerns about the future of innovation.

headline.main: Apple Case Muddies the Future of Innovations
headline.print_headline: Apple Case Muddies the Future of Innovations

snippet: Mark Stadnyk is suing the United States government, aiming to block a patent law that he says is a triumph of corporate lobbying that will hurt lone inventors like him.
abstract: Inventor Mark Stadnyk, who holds a patent on a motorcycle windshield, is suing the United States government, aiming to block a patent law, America Invents Act, that he says is triumph of corporate lobbying that will hurt lone inventors like himself; law would award patents to inventors who are 'first to file' with the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

headline.main: Inventor Challenges a Sweeping Revision in Patent Law
headline.print_headline: An Inventor Weighs In on Patents
